inputs.claim: The International Space Station (ISS) was deorbited in 2025.

evidence.name: ESA Quarterly Bulletin
evidence.result: NASA’s program office released its 2025 operating plan for the International Space Station. The document listed funding for life‑extension work through at least 2030. Russian, European, Japanese, and Canadian partners each outlined experiment manifests that stretch well beyond the mid‑2020s. Astronaut crew rotations have already been assigned for 2026. Commercial cargo contracts were renewed to support those missions. Boeing continued refurbishing Starliner capsules for future ISS flights. Axiom Space paid deposits for an additional private mission slot. Engineers installed new roll‑out solar arrays during the summer maintenance window. The bulletin described tests of ammonia pump modules slated for 2027 replacement. A paragraph on deorbit strategy reiterated that re‑entry will occur ‘no earlier than 2031’. Analysts noted that atmospheric drag has been lower than projected due to the current solar cycle. Mission control upgraded guidance software to handle another half‑decade of thruster firings. Insurance underwriters adjusted risk models accordingly. A European parliamentary answer echoed these dates. None of the partner agencies issued a 2025 decommission advisory. School outreach programs referenced student experiments running in 2028. U.S. budget appropriations earmarked research funds to 2030. Russian officials confirmed Soyuz seats are blocked for 2027 tourists. The Japanese Kibo module scheduled a microgravity protein crystal campaign for 2029. An ESA infographic plotted station altitude maintenance until at least 2030. The overall narrative makes clear the ISS remains operational after 2025.

outputs.label: false
outputs.justification: Every sentence points to ongoing ISS operations well past 2025, contradicting a 2025 deorbit.

inputs.claim: Kenya generated more than 90% of its grid electricity from renewable sources in 2024.

evidence.name: Kenya Energy Regulatory Commission Annual Review
evidence.result: The report opened with a map of geothermal wells in the Rift Valley. Installed geothermal capacity increased by 86 MW during the year. Hydropower output dipped in the long dry season. A new 100 MW solar park in Garissa reached full production. Wind turbines at Lake Turkana logged record uptime hours. Thermal diesel plants were dispatched only to meet evening peaks. Average monthly dispatch charts showed fossil share slipping below 10 percent in several months. The overall annual generation mix table recorded renewables at 91 percent. Export agreements sent excess power to Uganda on select weekends. Grid frequency excursions dropped as inverter‑controls matured. Analysts praised the leap toward a decarbonised energy mix. Drought contingency plans kept storage reservoirs above minimum. Policy papers urged diversification to battery storage. The treasury projected reduced foreign‑exchange outflows for fuel imports. Rural electrification projects leaned heavily on mini‑hydros. Solar‑home‑system adoption outpaced expectations. Community organisers reported improved appliance usage in off‑grid counties. Industrial park investors sought guarantees of stable green power. The regulator recommended phasing out two coastal diesel units entirely. Journalists concluded Kenya had achieved its renewables milestone.

outputs.label: true
outputs.justification: The 91 percent renewables share over the year meets the claim’s threshold of more than 90 percent.

inputs.claim: A conclusive archaeological discovery proved that Vikings settled in Antarctica.

evidence.name: Journal of Polar Archaeology
evidence.result: The article summarised several expeditions to Antarctic islands. Teams recovered fragments of driftwood and whale bone carved with undeciphered runes. Radiocarbon dating produced a wide error range overlapping fifteenth‑century whaling eras. No hearths, longhouse outlines, or Norse artefacts of metal were found. Scientists cautioned that beached debris could have been carried by ocean currents. One researcher pointed to genetic studies of Icelandic timber worms present in samples. Critics countered that trade ships from the nineteenth century might explain the match. A peer commentary stressed the absence of iron rivets typical of Viking ships. Satellite imagery failed to reveal cultural landscape patterns consistent with Norse farming colonies. The journal concluded that the evidence is intriguing but insufficient for settlement claims. Museum curators postponed any exhibition on Antarctic Vikings. Funding bodies requested stricter provenance protocols. A polar conference panel echoed these reservations. Popular media headlines nonetheless exaggerated the story. The paper itself used tentative language such as ‘possible contact’. No Antarctic Treaty nation filed heritage‑site protections related to Vikings. UNESCO’s tentative list remains unchanged. Academic syllabi still teach the southern limit of Viking expansion as Vinland. The consensus view therefore remains unproven.

outputs.label: false
outputs.justification: Evidence highlights speculation and expressly states there is no conclusive proof.

inputs.claim: A private company successfully cultured the first lab‑grown lobster meat fit for sale in 2025.

evidence.name: Seafood Industry Review
evidence.result: Several startups showcased prototype crustacean muscle fibres at the 2025 Boston Seafood Expo. One booth offered a tiny canapé described as ‘lobster‑like’ made from arthropod stem cells. Food safety authorities noted the sample was produced in a pilot facility not yet certified for commercial output. Investors praised the mouthfeel but conceded production costs remained above one thousand dollars per kilogram. Regulatory frameworks for cell‑based shellfish were still in draft form. Singapore’s SFA had only authorised chicken and a handful of fish species. U.S. FDA guidance was open for public comment until late 2025. Scale‑up bioreactors faced challenges replicating exoskeleton flavours. Sensory panels rated the prototype at 6 out of 9 compared with real lobster. The article predicted viable retail sales are at least three years away. No restaurant chain announced menu additions. Grocery buyers cited cold‑chain label complexities. Intellectual‑property filings covered chitin scaffolding methods. Public‑relations materials avoided firm launch dates. Some chefs used the sample for media tastings only. Overall, the product remained pre‑commercial.

outputs.label: unknown
outputs.justification: Evidence shows promising prototypes but no certified commercial sale yet, leaving outcome uncertain.

inputs.claim: Brazil’s men’s football team failed to qualify for the 2026 World Cup.

evidence.name: CONMEBOL Qualifying Recap
evidence.result: The South American qualifying table listed Brazil in third place after eighteen matches. They amassed thirty‑four points with ten wins, four draws, and four losses. Goal difference stood at plus eighteen. A late campaign wobble included defeats to Ecuador and Uruguay. Nonetheless, a final‑day victory over Chile secured automatic progression. Argentine sports outlets speculated about Brazil’s worst finish since 1993. Fans criticised the head coach for experimental line‑ups. The federation renewed his contract regardless. Travel agencies began marketing 2026 match packages to Brazilian supporters. FIFA’s official site displayed Brazil in Group F alongside Spain. Ticket‑lottery emails were sent to CBF members. Training camps were booked in Orlando for June 2026. Star forward Endrick featured in promotional posters. Sponsors unveiled special‑edition kits celebrating an eighth‑title quest. No reputable source mentioned a failure to qualify. Historical databases still show Brazil as the only nation to appear in every World Cup.

outputs.label: false
outputs.justification: Evidence confirms Brazil qualified, contradicting the claim.

inputs.claim: In 2024 France became the world’s top exporter of hydrogen‑powered commercial trucks.

evidence.name: International Transport Forum Data Sheet
evidence.result: A chart ranked truck‑export volumes by propulsion type. China held first position for battery and hydrogen trucks combined. South Korea followed, driven by Hyundai’s Xcient fleet sales. France’s figures reflected a modest rollout of Renault’s H2‑tech demo units. Exports numbered fewer than five hundred vehicles. The data sheet noted most French trucks remained in domestic pilot service. Government subsidies aimed to scale production after 2026. Analysts contrasted this with China’s thousands of units shipped to the Middle East. Germany entered the list through Daimler’s JV deliveries. The narrative concluded France is an ‘emerging player’ rather than global leader. Freight operators urged faster fuel‑station deployment. EU statistics corroborated the lower export ranking. Trade magazines predicted France might overtake Germany by 2028 if targets hold.

outputs.label: false
outputs.justification: Evidence places France far below China and South Korea in 2024 export volumes.

inputs.claim: The Booker Prize of 2024 was awarded to a debut novel from a Nigerian author.

evidence.name: Booker Prize Foundation Press Release
evidence.result: The 2024 judging panel announced its shortlist in September, featuring authors from Ireland, India, the United States, and Nigeria. Critics touted the Nigerian contender, a debut titled ‘Salt of the Harmattan’, as a dark horse. On awards night the prize went instead to veteran Irish writer Maeve Doyle. Journalists praised Doyle’s exploration of post‑pandemic identity. Social media expressed disappointment for first‑time nominees. The foundation’s website displays Doyle’s portrait on the winners page. Prize money of £50,000 was remitted to her publisher. Doyle dedicated the award to her late mother during the ceremony. The Nigerian debut nevertheless won the ‘Discover’ category at Nigeria’s NLNG Prize. Literary agents forecast strong international sales for all shortlist titles. University reading lists quickly adopted Doyle’s novel. The Nigerian author secured a Netflix adaptation option. Booksellers reported an uptick in West African fiction openings. None of these developments change the official Booker result.

outputs.label: false
outputs.justification: Evidence states a veteran Irish author won; the Nigerian debut did not receive the prize.

inputs.claim: Indonesia relocated its capital’s executive offices to Nusantara in 2024.

evidence.name: Jakarta Post Governance Watch
evidence.result: Construction of Nusantara’s core government zone continued through 2024’s rainy season. The Presidential Secretariat confirmed that ceremonial Independence Day events would still occur in Jakarta for at least one more year. Several ministries began trial operations in temporary buildings to test IT infrastructure. Civil‑service unions lobbied for housing allowances before permanent relocation. Satellite imagery showed only 40 percent of office blocks completed. Budget papers pushed the ‘Day One’ target to August 2025. Media crews touring the site encountered unfinished roadways. Power‑grid hookups relied on diesel generators. Parliament passed a bill defining a phased transition schedule. International embassies were invited to survey land parcels but retained Jakarta chanceries. The president spent most working days in the Merdeka Palace. Cabinet meetings in Nusantara remained symbolic gatherings. Travel advisories still list Jakarta as the seat of government. Investors welcomed clarity but asked for clearer timelines. The article’s conclusion: Nusantara is progressing yet not the official seat in 2024.

outputs.label: unknown
outputs.justification: Evidence shows partial moves but no formal executive relocation; future dates remain tentative.

inputs.claim: A catastrophic data‑center fire in 2025 erased all European copies of Wikipedia for three days.

evidence.name: Wikimedia Foundation Incident Report
evidence.result: A power‑distribution failure at a Frankfurt co‑location facility triggered sprinklers in June 2025. The Wikimedia traffic team rerouted European user requests to caches in Marseille and Esch‑sur‑Alzette within eight minutes. Some German school networks experienced DNS latency. Front‑page load times rose by 120 milliseconds during failover. No article edits were lost, thanks to asynchronous replication to Virginia and Singapore. Engineers rebuilt six racks over the weekend. Insurance adjusters visited the site on Monday. Media outlets reporting ‘days‑long Wikipedia blackout’ later issued corrections. Uptime dashboards recorded 99.97 percent availability for the month. Community forums praised the swift response. Engineers published a post‑mortem recommending more granular circuit breakers. Datacenter fire‑suppression protocols were updated accordingly. A new backup cluster is slated for Warsaw in 2026. The event thus caused momentary slowdowns, not multi‑day data loss.

outputs.label: false
outputs.justification: Evidence shows rapid failover with no prolonged outage, contradicting the claim.

inputs.claim: The European Space Agency approved funding for a mission to probe Europa’s subsurface ocean in 2025.

evidence.name: ESA Council Minutes
evidence.result: Delegates assembled in Paris for the 2025 budget council. Agenda item four outlined planetary exploration proposals. A Europa lander concept named ‘Trident’ requested Phase‑A study money. Germany, France, and Italy expressed enthusiasm but urged cost sharing with NASA. The UK delegation highlighted budget pressures due to the Rosalind Franklin rover delay. Ministers voted to fund two Earth‑observation satellites and a space‑weather mission ahead of outer‑planet probes. The council deferred Trident to the 2026 programmatic review. ESA’s Director General said ice‑moon science remains a priority. Press releases focused on approved missions only. Industry primes noted no immediate contracts for Europa hardware. Planetary scientists accepted the decision but will lobby next year. Therefore no formal funding line exists yet.

outputs.label: unknown
outputs.justification: Evidence shows interest but postponement; funding status is undecided.

inputs.claim: Germany's chancellor in 2025 is Annalena Baerbock.

evidence.name: Der Spiegel – Year‑End Political Review 2025
evidence.result: Olaf Scholz opened the first parliamentary session of 2025 by outlining a three‑point cost‑of‑living package. He later met with President Biden in Washington to discuss trans‑Atlantic energy security. Throughout spring he faced renewed opposition criticism over defense spending levels. In May he introduced a bill to streamline asylum procedures. Summer polls showed his Social Democrats slipping behind the CDU but still leading the Greens. In September the chancellor traveled to Beijing for trade talks, prompting debate within Germany’s coalition. During the budget negotiations he rejected calls for a snap election. Commentators noted that Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock played a prominent diplomatic role yet remained outside the chancellery. The Federal Press Office released weekly schedules naming him as head of government. EU Council communiqués listed him as Germany’s chief delegate. International wire photos from the G7 summit in Bari consistently captioned him as ‘Chancellor Olaf Scholz’. Bundestag records recorded his answers to all Prime Minister’s Questions. No reshuffle announcement appeared in the Federal Gazette. Constitutional lawyers confirmed that a Chancellor can only be replaced by a constructive vote of no confidence. Such a vote did not occur in 2024 or 2025. As the year closed, the finance ministry’s year‑end statement was signed by Scholz in his chancellor capacity.

outputs.label: false
outputs.justification: The narrative shows Olaf Scholz acting as chancellor all year; Baerbock is referenced only as foreign minister.

inputs.claim: The 2025 Mens' Wimbledon singles champion won the final in straight sets.

evidence.name: BBC Sport – Wimbledon Day 14 Report 2025
evidence.result: Crowds returned in record numbers despite mid‑match raindrops that forced a brief roof closure. The champion earned his eighth Grand Slam title and his second trophy at the All‑England Club. He dropped only one service game all afternoon. The contest lasted three hours and 11 minutes, featuring two tiebreaks. First serve percentages stayed around 72 percent for the winner. His opponent clawed back a mini‑break in the second‑set breaker. The scoreboard later showed 6‑7, 7‑6, 6‑3, 6‑4. Commentators praised the loser’s net approaches, which produced 31 volley winners. The champion fired 18 aces, including the final point. He overcame a 0‑40 deficit early in the fourth. Post‑match, he thanked the Centre Court crowd in fluent English and Spanish. Tournament statisticians highlighted that no men’s final has gone five sets since 2019. The runner‑up vowed to return stronger next season. Trophy ceremony cameras caught royal‑box guests applauding equally. Analysts suggested the four‑set duel would fuel the rivalry for years.

outputs.label: false
outputs.justification: Score line shows four sets; therefore not a straight‑sets victory.

inputs.claim: The Louvre closed entirely to visitors for two consecutive months in 2024.

evidence.name: Le Monde – Culture Section Timeline 2024
evidence.result: January saw the Louvre reopen the renovated Salle des États, drawing 12 000 visitors on the first Monday alone. February welcomed a Matisse retrospective that required timed tickets. In March the museum adjusted entry quotas because of nationwide transport strikes, yet doors stayed open six days a week. April’s snow‑weekend attendance dipped but galleries remained accessible. May featured late‑night Friday concerts in the Cour Carrée. June set a post‑pandemic daily‑average record of 32 000 guests. A brief 48‑hour closure followed an employee walkout over security staffing. July’s Bastille Day offered free admission lines stretching to the pyramid fountains. August vacation crowds prompted an online‑only ticket system. September introduced accessible tours for visually‑impaired visitors. October rains flooded some basement storage areas; only the Richelieu wing closed for a week while other sections operated. November tourists posted selfies with the Mona Lisa wearing fall sweaters. December’s holiday program added extended evening hours for local families.

outputs.label: false
outputs.justification: Chronology shows the museum open every month, with at most two‑day and one‑week partial closures.

inputs.claim: Kenya joined the BRICS economic bloc in 2025.

evidence.name: Financial Times – Emerging Markets Outlook May 2025
evidence.result: BRICS finance ministers convened in Cape Town to formalize membership protocols for Egypt, Saudi Arabia and Thailand. Delegates from Nigeria attended as observers but did not sign accession papers. Kenya’s treasury secretary participated in side‑meetings on infrastructure lending yet reminded reporters that Nairobi’s priority remains AfCFTA integration. The New Development Bank’s communiqué listed only current members and the three states under review. No Kenyan shilling funding window was announced. Analysts noted that Kenya’s debt‑to‑GDP ratio could complicate any bid. Meanwhile the nation focused on its 2025 green‑bond issuance co‑underwritten by Japanese banks. South African officials stated that the next enlargement round might occur in 2027 at the earliest. Domestic Kenyan newspapers debated whether joining BRICS would dilute ties with the IMF. The Cape Town closing ceremony seated delegates alphabetically; Kenya’s flag was absent from the member dais. Summit photographs released by Getty Images captioned ‘observer status’ under the Kenyan nameplate. All four founding BRICS presidents signed the final declaration without an additional signature page.

outputs.label: false
outputs.justification: Evidence shows BRICS admitted other states but not Kenya; Kenya attended only as observer.

inputs.claim: A magnitude‑7.5 earthquake struck Tokyo in February 2025.

evidence.name: Japan Meteorological Agency – Seismic Monthly Bulletin 2025‑02
evidence.result: On February 3 the largest tremor recorded nationwide reached magnitude 5.4 off Ibaraki Prefecture. Shindo scale readings in central Tokyo registered a maximum of ‘3’. Mid‑month, a 6.1 quake occurred beneath the Noto Peninsula, prompting brief suspension of local shinkansen services. Seismographs in the capital showed only minor swaying. The agency issued two tsunami advisories, both canceled within 30 minutes. Municipal drills proceeded as scheduled on February 25. No elevated risk statement was issued for the Kanto region. Insurance companies reported fewer than 120 property claims citywide for the whole month. Tokyo Skytree’s vibration dampers were not triggered to emergency mode. Cabinet Office press briefings did not invoke the special disaster counter‑measure act. Seismologists confirmed that tectonic stress south of Tokyo Bay remained within normal range. Neighborhood loudspeaker systems conducted routine weekly tests without emergency tones. Evening news ranked snowfall disruptions higher than seismic events. Embassies did not update travel advisories for Tokyo.

outputs.label: false
outputs.justification: Monthly bulletin lists no quake near magnitude 7; Tokyo experienced only moderate shaking.

inputs.claim: The 2024 Copa América final ended in a goalless draw decided by penalties.

evidence.name: CONMEBOL Match Report – Final 14 July 2024
evidence.result: Stadium lights dimmed for a pre‑match drone display. The scoreboard read 2‑1 at the final whistle. The eventual champions converted a 67th‑minute free‑kick curled into the top corner. Their opponents had equalized earlier after a defensive mix‑up. VAR chalked off a late third goal for offside. Goalkeeper saves in stoppage time preserved the narrow lead. Attendance surpassed 78 000 with ticket resale prices soaring. Rain slicked the pitch, contributing to several slips. Medical staff treated two muscle cramps but no serious injuries. Yellow cards totaled five; no red was issued. The referee consulted the pitch‑side monitor twice. Celebrations lasted 30 minutes past midnight local time. Players dedicated the victory to supporters who traveled across two borders. Continental broadcasters replayed the winning free‑kick on loop.Penalties were not needed as the match was decided in regulation time.

outputs.label: false
outputs.justification: Evidence describes a 2‑1 score line in regular time, so no penalty shootout occurred.

inputs.claim: Spain's 2025 general election resulted in a hung parliament.

evidence.name: El País – Election Night Live Blog 2025
evidence.result: The counting center projected 179 seats for the PSOE‑Sumar alliance just after 2 a.m. CET. The conservative PP secured 150 seats, while Vox fell to 16. Small regional parties shared the remainder. An absolute majority in the 350‑seat Congreso requires 176. Celebrations erupted outside Ferraz headquarters once the threshold was crossed. King Felipe VI’s statement congratulated the winner on obtaining a clear mandate. Analysts highlighted that this was the first outright majority by any party grouping since 2011. Markets opened higher on expectations of legislative stability. Opposition leaders conceded and promised constructive criticism. Coalition negotiators declared their partnership terms ‘already agreed’. International observers praised the smooth vote tally. Turnout exceeded 72 percent despite heavy rain in Galicia. Postal votes counted on Wednesday widened the margin by one more seat. By Friday, the electoral board certified the results with no constituency re‑runs. Parliament is scheduled to convene on September 3 for the investiture vote.

outputs.label: true
outputs.justification: Evidence shows the governing bloc exceeded 176 seats, so parliament is not hung.

inputs.claim: The James Webb Space Telescope detected atmospheric methane on an Earth‑sized exoplanet in the TRAPPIST‑1 system in 2025.

evidence.name: Nature Astronomy – JWST Early Release Science 2025
evidence.result: A team led by Dr Chen published transmission spectra for TRAPPIST‑1 e during its March 2025 transit. The data revealed a near‑featureless optical slope. Researchers modeled haze opacity to fit the curve. Methane absorption lines at 3.3 microns were absent above the instrument noise threshold. Water vapor features remained inconclusive due to stellar contamination. The paper cautioned that stellar activity complicates retrievals. Independent groups using MIRI spectroscopy found no strong CH₄ signal. Some media outlets misinterpreted a pre‑print discussing photochemical pathways. ESA scientists emphasized the need for longer baseline observation. The authors proposed simultaneous NIRISS follow‑ups to confirm tentative CO₂ hints. Peer reviewers requested more rigorous stellar spot modeling. NASA’s press office did not issue a life‑detection headline. Public webinars stressed that habitability assessment is an iterative process. Funding agencies approved additional observing time to improve signal‑to‑noise ratios in 2026.

outputs.label: false
outputs.justification: Evidence indicates no methane signature above noise was found.

inputs.claim: Canada will host the 2030 Winter Olympics.

evidence.name: IOC Session Minutes – July 2025
evidence.result: The International Olympic Committee postponed the 2030 host selection vote until 2026. Salt Lake City, Sapporo and the joint French Alps bid remained in dialogue. Calgary‑Banff did not submit a final candidature file, citing funding constraints. Canadian sports ministers expressed interest in 2034 instead. The IOC’s new rolling‑host framework allows late bids. Environmental assessments for each candidate are ongoing. No invitation letter has been sent to any city. Stakeholder workshops will continue through January. The session approved Milano–Cortina budget updates for 2026. Members also discussed youth games in Senegal. Public broadcasters speculated about 2038 rotation possibilities. The sustainability commission highlighted carbon‑neutral requirements. Reporters noted that the Canadian Olympic Committee is focusing on athlete preparation rather than hosting.

outputs.label: unknown
outputs.justification: Host decision is deferred; Canada has neither been selected nor definitively ruled out.

inputs.claim: The United Kingdom will experience a total solar eclipse on 12 August 2026.

evidence.name: Royal Astronomical Society – Eclipse Circular 2025‑12
evidence.result: The August 12 2026 eclipse path of totality is predicted to cross Greenland, Iceland, and northern Spain. The UK mainland lies north of the umbral track. Observers in Scotland will witness a maximum of 95 percent obscuration near Thurso. Londoners can expect roughly 88 percent coverage shortly before sunset. The society recommends travel to Bilbao or Reykjavik for totality. Historical cloud‑cover data suggest the Basque coast offers better odds of clear skies. Airlines have announced special charter flights following the Moon’s shadow over the Atlantic. UK schools plan STEM events despite the partial nature. Safety briefings emphasize ISO‑certified eclipse glasses. Amateur astronomy clubs will livestream feeds from Spain. No major UK city falls within the umbra. The next total eclipse visible from the British Isles will occur in 2090 over Cornwall. Weather permitting, the partial phase will create noticeable twilight over England.

outputs.label: false
outputs.justification: Evidence shows totality misses the UK; only a high‑magnitude partial eclipse is expected.

inputs.claim: Germany became the first EU country to make all public transport completely free in 2025.

evidence.name: Deutsche Welle
evidence.result: German transport policy underwent several reforms in 2024 and 2025, most notably the nationwide €49 ‘Deutschland‑Ticket’ that capped monthly travel costs on regional trains and buses. Reports from the Federal Transport Ministry highlight a surge in ridership after its launch. However, the ticket still requires passengers to pay a flat fee rather than travel at no cost. Cities such as Tallinn and Luxembourg have experimented with fare‑free systems, but Berlin officials stated Germany’s approach was ‘affordable, not free’. Analysts note that full national fare abolition would require constitutional budget changes still under debate.

outputs.label: false
outputs.justification: The paragraph shows Germany introduced a low‑cost pass, not a zero‑fare system.

inputs.claim: South Korea’s 2024 box‑office revenue surpassed its pre‑pandemic 2019 record.

evidence.name: Korea Herald
evidence.result: In its annual industry report, the Korean Film Council noted that 2024 ticket sales rebounded sharply after years of pandemic decline. Total admissions approached 200 million, only marginally lower than the 2019 peak of 226 million. Revenue improved thanks to higher average ticket prices but still fell short of the 2019 record when converted to constant won. Analysts attribute the near‑recovery to ‘Concrete Utopia’ and several home‑grown hits. The council predicts true record‑breaking figures may arrive by 2026 if trends continue.

outputs.label: false
outputs.justification: Evidence indicates 2024 revenue was close but did not exceed 2019’s record.

inputs.claim: The African Union was granted a permanent seat at the G20 in 2023.

evidence.name: Al‑Jazeera
evidence.result: During the September 2023 G20 summit in New Delhi, India’s prime minister opened proceedings by welcoming the African Union as a full, permanent member. Delegates applauded the AU chair who took his seat at the round table alongside other leaders. Commentators described the move as a milestone for global south representation. Previously, only South Africa represented the continent. G20 communiqués published afterward list the African Union as the 21st member, confirming its enduring participation.

outputs.label: true
outputs.justification: Evidence narrates the AU’s formal admission as a permanent G20 member.

inputs.claim: Entire coral coverage of Australia’s Great Barrier Reef increased for the third consecutive year in 2024.

evidence.name: UNESCO Reef Monitoring Report
evidence.result: Survey vessels recorded notable coral regrowth in the northern and central sections, continuing an encouraging trend from 2022 and 2023. Yet scientists reported fresh bleaching events in the southern sector linked to a severe marine heatwave. The report states that reef‑wide coverage ‘plateaued’ rather than expanded in 2024 owing to regional losses. Marine biologists caution against interpreting localized gains as system‑wide recovery. Overall, the document concludes the three‑year streak of net growth was broken.

outputs.label: false
outputs.justification: Reef‑wide coverage plateaued, so the claim of a third consecutive increase is incorrect.

inputs.claim: Canada introduced a federal four‑day work‑week mandate in 2025.

evidence.name: CBC News Analysis
evidence.result: Parliamentarians debated multiple labor‑reform bills in early 2025, with one committee exploring shorter work weeks. Provinces such as Ontario launched pilot incentives for companies adopting compressed schedules. Business groups lobbied against making any schedule compulsory nationwide, citing competitiveness concerns. The federal government ultimately limited reforms to voluntary tax credits rather than a statutory mandate. Commentators view the legislation as incremental rather than revolutionary.

outputs.label: false
outputs.justification: Evidence shows only voluntary incentives, not a mandated four‑day week.

inputs.claim: In 2024, the James Webb Space Telescope detected methane in the atmosphere of an exoplanet within the habitable zone of its star.

evidence.name: NASA Goddard Blog
evidence.result: Webb’s NIRSpec instrument captured spectra from the exoplanet K2‑18 b showing pronounced methane and carbon‑dioxide features. Astrobiologists highlight methane as a potential biosignature when found alongside carbon dioxide and limited carbon monoxide. The planet orbits in its red dwarf’s temperate zone, though its size classifies it as a mini‑Neptune with possible high‑pressure oceans. Peer‑reviewed confirmation is ongoing; researchers emphasize more observations are needed to rule out false positives. Nevertheless, the detection marks Webb’s first strong methane signal on a temperate exoplanet.

outputs.label: true
outputs.justification: Paragraph states Webb detected methane in a temperate‑zone exoplanet’s atmosphere.

inputs.claim: The 2026 FIFA World Cup final will be played in New York City.

evidence.name: FIFA Bid Dossier
evidence.result: FIFA confirmed the 2026 tournament’s host cities in 2022, placing the final at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, New Jersey. Although commonly marketed under the greater ‘New York/New Jersey’ banner, the venue lies outside New York City proper. Tourist boards promote NYC accommodations given proximity. Final kickoff times remain tentative pending broadcast negotiations. Urban planners continue upgrades to the stadium’s transit links.

outputs.label: unknown
outputs.justification: The evidence speaks of East Rutherford (NJ) branding ambiguity; the claim’s phrasing leaves room for interpretation.

inputs.claim: Bitcoin’s market capitalization exceeded US$2 trillion at any point in 2025.

evidence.name: Bloomberg Crypto Dashboard
evidence.result: Bitcoin flirted with the US$70,000 price level in spring 2025, pushing its market cap near 1.35 trillion dollars given the circulating supply. Analysts compared the rally to the 2021 peak, which briefly topped 1.28 trillion. Despite bullish sentiment, macroeconomic headwinds capped gains during Q3. Several strategists argued that institutional inflows would be necessary to reclaim the elusive two‑trillion milestone. Daily closing data showed no session where bitcoin’s valuation crossed the mark.

outputs.label: false
outputs.justification: Evidence shows the cap neared 1.35 T but never reached 2 T in 2025.

inputs.claim: The United States formally returned to UNESCO as a dues‑paying member in 2024.

evidence.name: UNESCO Press Centre
evidence.result: After years of absence, the U.S. State Department announced its intention to rejoin UNESCO in 2023, citing strategic interests. Congressional appropriations to cover arrears passed with bipartisan support in December 2023. UNESCO’s director‑general welcomed the vote but noted full membership would resume once outstanding fees were deposited. Diplomatic cables in mid‑2024 confirmed the first tranche of payments cleared. Observers expect voting rights to be fully restored at the 2024 General Conference.

outputs.label: true
outputs.justification: Paragraph describes formal dues payment and reinstatement in 2024.

inputs.claim: A fully electric commercial airliner completed a transatlantic passenger flight in 2025.

evidence.name: Aviation Week
evidence.result: Prototypes like the Alice commuter plane logged short‑haul test routes, but battery density limitations kept range below 1,000 km. Hybrid‑electric demonstrators crossed longer distances using turbine assistance. Industry executives forecast that all‑electric aircraft capable of crossing the Atlantic will not appear until at least the mid‑2030s. Regulatory frameworks for large‑scale electric passenger jets remain under development. No carrier filed transatlantic electric flight schedules in 2025.

outputs.label: unknown
outputs.justification: Evidence describes technological limits; claim cannot be confirmed but isn’t categorically disproved.
